Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story:
I glanced at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my sister. “Don’t be late! Mom’s counting on you to help set up.” Today was the big family holiday dinner, and I’d promised I’d be there early. But here I was, behind the wheel of my taxi, running late after a last-minute fare. My mind raced with guilt—my family expected me to show up, to be present, to help make the day special.

As I turned onto Maple Street, orange cones forced all traffic into a single lane. Up ahead, a cluster of children waited at the curb, backpacks slung over their shoulders. The school zone lights flashed insistently. I felt the pressure mounting: if I slowed down, I’d be even later, risking my family’s disappointment. But as a taxi driver, I knew the rules—school zones meant strict speed limits, extra caution, no exceptions. My hands tightened on the wheel, heart pounding. I could almost hear my mom’s voice, hopeful and expectant, and at the same time, the stern reminder from my training: safety first, always. I hesitated, caught between the demands of my family and the responsibility of my job, unsure which way to turn.
